messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Mimi question...
messages.msgSnippet: Pete, Barry was pretty well there. From Haynes and Torigoye Uchikaeshi-mimi: The edge of the tsuba rolled and beaten onto the plate surface. Kohineriu-mimi: A
messages.messageBody:
Pete, Barry was pretty well there. From Haynes and Torigoye

Uchikaeshi-mimi: The edge of the tsuba rolled and beaten onto the plate
surface.

Kohineriu-mimi: A type of Uchikaeshi-mimi that has a slight twist to the
rolled over edge.

So I am thinking Kohinerikaeshi-mimi is the same of Kohineriu-mimi.

Hope that helps

Rich

klepet33319 wrote:

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Mimi question...
messages.msgSnippet: Hmmm - off the top of my head, ko = small or little, hineri is a pinch or a twist (term used in aikido), and kaeri means a return or a turn-back (term
messages.messageBody:
Hmmm - off the top of my head, "ko"= small or little, "hineri" is a pinch or a twist (term used in aikido), and "kaeri" means a "return" or a turn-back (term used in swords). So, I'm guessing it is a mimi that might be rope-like with small twists with an under-curve like a scraper used in woodwork???? As for a picture...

Barry Thomas.
